Implement the following plan:

# Plan: Children's Stories Section for BSM Website

## Context
The BSM website has an `/articles` section (3 deity articles) recently merged to main. Instead of having separate `/articles` and `/stories` sections (too noisy), we'll **merge everything into one `/stories` section** -- 12 new children's stories at the top, existing 3 articles moved below as "Articles / Deep Reads".

## What Changes

### Move existing articles into `/stories` (3 files moved)
| From | To |
|------|-----|
| `articles/durga-slays-mahishasura/page.tsx` | `stories/durga-slays-mahishasura/page.tsx` |
| `articles/goddess-saraswati/page.tsx` | `stories/goddess-saraswati/page.tsx` |
| `articles/kali-mata/page.tsx` | `stories/kali-mata/page.tsx` |

Update internal links in these files: `‚Üê Back to Articles` -> `‚Üê Back to Stories`, `href="/articles"` -> `href="/stories"`

### Delete old articles directory
| File | Action |
|------|--------|
| `frontend/src/app/articles/page.tsx` | Delete (replaced by `/stories/page.tsx`) |
| `frontend/src/app/articles/` directory | Delete entirely after moving files |

### Create new files (15 files)
| File | Purpose |
|------|---------|
| `frontend/src/app/stories/storyData.ts` | Types + 12 story metadata + 3 article metadata + helpers |
| `frontend/src/components/StoryPageLayout.tsx` | Shared layout for children's story pages |
| `frontend/src/app/stories/page.tsx` | Combined listing: children's stories (top) + articles (bottom) |

**12 children's story pages:**

| # | File | Story | Color |
|---|------|-------|-------|
| 1 | `stories/mahishasur-bodh/page.tsx` | The Slaying of Mahishasura (‡¶Æ‡¶π‡¶ø‡¶∑‡¶æ‡¶∏‡ßÅ‡¶∞ ‡¶¨‡¶ß) | Red |
| 2 | `stories/umar-agomoni/page.tsx` | Uma's Homecoming (‡¶â‡¶Æ‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶Ü‡¶ó‡¶Æ‡¶®‡ßÄ) | Red |
| 3 | `stories/durgar-dosh-ostro/page.tsx` | How Durga Got Her Ten Weapons (‡¶¶‡ßÅ‡¶∞‡ßç‡¶ó‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶¶‡¶∂ ‡¶Ö‡¶∏‡ßç‡¶§‡ßç‡¶∞) | Red |
| 4 | `stories/saraswatir-binadan/page.tsx` | The Gift of Music and Speech (‡¶∏‡¶∞‡¶∏‡ßç‡¶¨‡¶§‡ßÄ‡¶∞ ‡¶¨‡ßÄ‡¶£‡¶æ‡¶¶‡¶æ‡¶®) | Yellow |
| 5 | `stories/hatekhari/page.tsx` | The First Writing Lesson (‡¶π‡¶æ‡¶§‡ßá‡¶ñ‡¶°‡¶º‡¶ø) | Yellow |
| 6 | `stories/saraswati-o-ondhokar/page.tsx` | Saraswati's Light Against Darkness (‡¶∏‡¶∞‡¶∏‡ßç‡¶¨‡¶§‡ßÄ ‡¶ì ‡¶Ö‡¶®‡ßç‡¶ß‡¶ï‡¶æ‡¶∞) | Yellow |
| 7 | `stories/ganesher-gajanon/page.tsx` | How Ganesh Got His Elephant Head (‡¶ó‡¶£‡ßá‡¶∂‡ßá‡¶∞ ‡¶ó‡¶ú‡¶æ‡¶®‡¶® ‡¶ï‡¶æ‡¶π‡¶ø‡¶®‡ßÄ) | Orange |
| 8 | `stories/prithivi-prodokshin/page.tsx` | The Race Around the World (‡¶™‡ßÉ‡¶•‡¶ø‡¶¨‡ßÄ ‡¶™‡ßç‡¶∞‡¶¶‡¶ï‡ßç‡¶∑‡¶ø‡¶£) | Orange |
| 9 | `stories/ganesher-mahabharot-lekha/page.tsx` | Ganesh Writes the Mahabharata (‡¶ó‡¶£‡ßá‡¶∂‡ßá‡¶∞ ‡¶Æ‡¶π‡¶æ‡¶≠‡¶æ‡¶∞‡¶§ ‡¶≤‡ßá‡¶ñ‡¶æ) | Orange |
| 10 | `stories/kartikayer-jonmo/page.tsx` | Birth of Kartikeya (‡¶ï‡¶æ‡¶∞‡ßç‡¶§‡¶ø‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶Ø‡¶º‡ßá‡¶∞ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡ßç‡¶Æ) | Blue |
| 11 | `stories/kartiker-moyur-bahon/page.tsx` | How Kartikeya Got His Peacock (‡¶ï‡¶æ‡¶∞‡ßç‡¶§‡¶ø‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶∞ ‡¶Æ‡¶Ø‡¶º‡ßÇ‡¶∞-‡¶¨‡¶æ‡¶π‡¶®) | Blue |
| 12 | `stories/gonesh-kartik-bibad/page.tsx` | The Great Sibling Rivalry (‡¶ó‡¶£‡ßá‡¶∂-‡¶ï‡¶æ‡¶∞‡ßç‡¶§‡¶ø‡¶ï ‡¶¨‡¶ø‡¶¨‡¶æ‡¶¶) | Blue |

### Modify existing files (3 files)
| File | Change |
|------|--------|

| `Footer.tsx` | Replace articles link -> stories link |
| `sitemap.ts` | Remove `/articles` URLs, add `/stories` + all 15 story/article URLs |

## Listing Page Layout (`/stories/page.tsx`)
1. **Hero** -- "Stories & Articles / ‡¶ó‡¶≤‡ßç‡¶™ ‡¶ì ‡¶™‡ßç‡¶∞‡¶¨‡¶®‡ßç‡¶ß"
2. **Divine Family intro** -- Brief section about the Durga-Ganesh-Kartikeya-Saraswati family
3. **Children's Stories** -- 4 deity sections (Durga, Saraswati, Ganesh, Kartikeya), 3 cards each
4. **Articles** -- "Articles / Deep Reads" section with the 3 existing article cards below

## Children's Story Page Structure
1. Hero with deity-colored gradient + optional puja photo
2. 3-4 narrative sections (alternating white/gray bg), English prose + Bengali callouts
3. Moral/Lesson callout section
4. Related stories from same deity
5. Prev/Next navigation + "All Stories" button

## Implementation Order
1. Create feature branch from main
2. Create `storyData.ts` + `StoryPageLayout.tsx`
3. Create `stories/page.tsx` (combined listing)
4. Move 3 article pages from `articles/` to `stories/`, update internal links
5. Delete `articles/` directory
6. Create 12 children's story pages
7. Update Header.tsx, Footer.tsx, sitemap.ts
8. Build + verify

## Verification
1. `npm run build` -- no errors
2. Manual check: `/stories` shows 12 story cards + 3 article cards
3. All 15 individual pages render correctly
4. Header/Footer links point to `/stories`
5. Mobile responsive layout works
6. Old `/articles` URLs return 404 (expected -- content moved to `/stories`)


If you need specific details from before exiting plan mode (like exact code snippets, error messages, or content you generated), read the full transcript at: /Users/manishmitra/.REDACTED.jsonl

38‚Üí The Legend of Durga Slaying Mahishasura 39‚Üí 40‚Üí ‡¶¶‡ßÅ‡¶∞‡ßç‡¶ó‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶Æ‡¶π‡¶ø‡¶∑‡¶æ‡¶∏‡ßÅ‡¶∞ ‡¶¨‡¶ß‡ßá‡¶∞ ‡¶ï‡¶æ‡¶π‡¶ø‡¶®‡ßÄ 41‚Üí 42‚Üí

43‚Üí

44‚Üí The epic tale of good triumphing over evil 45‚Üí

46‚Üí 47‚Üí
48‚Üí
49‚Üí 50‚Üí {/* The Story - Bilingual */} 51‚Üí

53‚Üí 60‚Üí

61‚Üí The Story 62‚Üí 63‚Üí ‡¶ï‡¶æ‡¶π‡¶ø‡¶®‡ßÄ 64‚Üí 65‚Üí

66‚Üí 67‚Üí 68‚Üí

78‚Üí 79‚Üí English 80‚Üí 81‚Üí
82‚Üí
83‚Üí

The Tyranny of Mahishasura

84‚Üí

85‚Üí Long ago, the demon Mahishasura ‚Äî the buffalo demon ‚Äî performed severe penance to please Lord Brahma. 86‚Üí Impressed by his devotion, Brahma granted him a boon: no god or demon could ever kill him. Emboldened 87‚Üí by this near-invincibility, Mahishasura waged war against the Devas (gods) and drove them out of heaven. 88‚Üí He terrorised the three worlds ‚Äî heaven, earth, and the netherworld ‚Äî plunging all of creation into 89‚Üí darkness and suffering. 90‚Üí

91‚Üí 92‚Üí

The Birth of Goddess Durga

93‚Üí

94‚Üí The defeated gods turned to the holy trinity ‚Äî Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva ‚Äî for help. In their fury 95‚Üí at Mahishasura's atrocities, all the gods combined their divine energies. From this blazing 96‚Üí convergence of cosmic power, a radiant female form emerged ‚Äî Goddess Durga, the embodiment of 97‚Üí Shakti (divine feminine energy). She was more powerful than any single deity, for she carried the 98‚Üí collective strength of all the gods within her. 99‚Üí

100‚Üí 101‚Üí

The Ten Arms and Divine Weapons

102‚Üí

103‚Üí Each god bestowed upon Durga their most powerful weapon. Shiva gave her his trident (trishul), 104‚Üí Vishnu his discus (sudarshana chakra), Indra his thunderbolt (vajra), Vayu gave his bow and arrows, 105‚Üí and Himavan gifted her a magnificent lion as her mount. With ten arms, each wielding a divine weapon, 106‚Üí Durga was the ultimate warrior ‚Äî beautiful yet fearsome, serene yet invincible. Her very form 107‚Üí symbolised the truth that when all righteous forces unite, no evil can withstand them. 108‚Üí

109‚Üí 110‚Üí

The Great Battle

111‚Üí

112‚Üí The battle between Durga and Mahishasura raged for nine days and nine nights. The demon king 113‚Üí changed his form repeatedly ‚Äî appearing as a buffalo, a lion, an elephant, and a warrior ‚Äî trying 114‚Üí every trick to overpower the goddess. But Durga matched him at every turn, her divine weapons 115‚Üí countering each transformation. The earth trembled, the seas roared, and the skies blazed with 116‚Üí the fury of their combat. 117‚Üí

118‚Üí 119‚Üí

The Victory ‚Äî Vijaya Dashami

120‚Üí

121‚Üí On the tenth day, as Mahishasura assumed his buffalo form once more, Durga leapt upon him, 122‚Üí pinning him with her foot. She drove her trident through his chest, and the great demon fell. 123‚Üí The heavens erupted in celebration. The gods showered flowers from the sky, and the three worlds 124‚Üí rejoiced. This day of triumph is celebrated as Vijaya Dashami (Dashami meaning the tenth day), 125‚Üí the culmination of Durga Puja. It represents the eternal promise that righteousness will always 126‚Üí prevail over evil, no matter how powerful the darkness may seem. 127‚Üí

128‚Üí

229‚Üí Durga Puja is the grandest festival for Bengalis worldwide. For five days each autumn, 230‚Üí communities come together to honour the Goddess through elaborate rituals, stunning pandal 231‚Üí decorations, cultural performances, and communal feasting. It is more than a religious 232‚Üí observance ‚Äî it is a celebration of art, community, homecoming, and the enduring human 233‚Üí belief in the triumph of good over evil. 234‚Üí

236‚Üí At the Bengali Society of Melbourne, Durgotsav is our most anticipated annual event. 237‚Üí It brings together Bengali families from across Victoria, recreating the warmth and spirit 238‚Üí of celebrations back home. From the rhythmic beats of the dhak to the fragrance of 239‚Üí dhunuchi, every element connects us to our heritage and to each other. 240‚Üí

The Legend of Durga Slaying Mahishasura ‡¶¶‡ßÅ‡¶∞‡ßç‡¶ó‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶Æ‡¶π‡¶ø‡¶∑‡¶æ‡¶∏‡ßÅ‡¶∞ ‡¶¨‡¶ß‡ßá‡¶∞ ‡¶ï‡¶æ‡¶π‡¶ø‡¶®‡ßÄ

The epic tale of good triumphing over evil

{/* The Story - Bilingual */}

The Story ‡¶ï‡¶æ‡¶π‡¶ø‡¶®‡ßÄ

{/* English Column */}
English

The Tyranny of Mahishasura

Long ago, the demon Mahishasura ‚Äî the buffalo demon ‚Äî performed severe penance to please Lord Brahma. Impressed by his devotion, Brahma granted him a boon: no god or demon could ever kill him. Emboldened by this near-invincibility, Mahishasura waged war against the Devas (gods) and drove them out of heaven. He terrorised the three worlds ‚Äî heaven, earth, and the netherworld ‚Äî plunging all of creation into darkness and suffering.

The Birth of Goddess Durga

The defeated gods turned to the holy trinity ‚Äî Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva ‚Äî for help. In their fury at Mahishasura's atrocities, all the gods combined their divine energies. From this blazing convergence of cosmic power, a radiant female form emerged ‚Äî Goddess Durga, the embodiment of Shakti (divine feminine energy). She was more powerful than any single deity, for she carried the collective strength of all the gods within her.

The Ten Arms and Divine Weapons

Each god bestowed upon Durga their most powerful weapon. Shiva gave her his trident (trishul), Vishnu his discus (sudarshana chakra), Indra his thunderbolt (vajra), Vayu gave his bow and arrows, and Himavan gifted her a magnificent lion as her mount. With ten arms, each wielding a divine weapon, Durga was the ultimate warrior ‚Äî beautiful yet fearsome, serene yet invincible. Her very form symbolised the truth that when all righteous forces unite, no evil can withstand them.

The Great Battle

The battle between Durga and Mahishasura raged for nine days and nine nights. The demon king changed his form repeatedly ‚Äî appearing as a buffalo, a lion, an elephant, and a warrior ‚Äî trying every trick to overpower the goddess. But Durga matched him at every turn, her divine weapons countering each transformation. The earth trembled, the seas roared, and the skies blazed with the fury of their combat.

The Victory ‚Äî Vijaya Dashami

On the tenth day, as Mahishasura assumed his buffalo form once more, Durga leapt upon him, pinning him with her foot. She drove her trident through his chest, and the great demon fell. The heavens erupted in celebration. The gods showered flowers from the sky, and the three worlds rejoiced. This day of triumph is celebrated as Vijaya Dashami (Dashami meaning the tenth day), the culmination of Durga Puja. It represents the eternal promise that righteousness will always prevail over evil, no matter how powerful the darkness may seem.

Why We Celebrate ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶® ‡¶Ü‡¶Æ‡¶∞‡¶æ ‡¶â‡¶¶‡¶Ø‡¶æ‡¶™‡¶® ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶ø

English

Durga Puja is the grandest festival for Bengalis worldwide. For five days each autumn, communities come together to honour the Goddess through elaborate rituals, stunning pandal decorations, cultural performances, and communal feasting. It is more than a religious observance ‚Äî it is a celebration of art, community, homecoming, and the enduring human belief in the triumph of good over evil.

At the Bengali Society of Melbourne, Durgotsav is our most anticipated annual event. It brings together Bengali families from across Victoria, recreating the warmth and spirit of celebrations back home. From the rhythmic beats of the dhak to the fragrance of dhunuchi, every element connects us to our heritage and to each other.

83‚Üí

The River of Knowledge

84‚Üí

85‚Üí Saraswati is one of the three great goddesses (Tridevi) of Hinduism, alongside Lakshmi and 86‚Üí Parvati. Her name comes from the Sanskrit words "Sara" (essence) and "Swa" 87‚Üí (self), meaning "the essence of the self". She is also named after the sacred 88‚Üí Saraswati River, which in Vedic literature represents the flow of knowledge and wisdom. 89‚Üí Just as a river nourishes the land through which it flows, Saraswati nourishes the mind 90‚Üí with learning, creativity, and insight. 91‚Üí

92‚Üí 93‚Üí

The Divine Iconography

94‚Üí

95‚Üí Saraswati is depicted as an ethereally beautiful goddess dressed in pure white, symbolising 96‚Üí the purity of true knowledge. She sits upon a white lotus, representing supreme reality 97‚Üí and transcendence. In her four hands, she carries the sacred symbols of her domain: 98‚Üí

99‚Üí
    100‚Üí
  • The Veena ‚Äî a stringed musical instrument representing the arts, music, and the harmony of life. It teaches that knowledge must be tuned to produce sweetness, not discord.
    • 101‚Üí
  • The Vedas (sacred scriptures) ‚Äî representing universal, divine, and eternal knowledge that transcends all boundaries of time and place.
    • 102‚Üí
  • A Mala (rosary) ‚Äî symbolising the power of meditation, spiritual discipline, and inner contemplation.
    • 103‚Üí
  • A Kamandalu (water pot) ‚Äî representing the purifying power of knowledge that cleanses the mind of ignorance.
    • 104‚Üí
105‚Üí 106‚Üí

The Swan and the Peacock

107‚Üí

108‚Üí Saraswati's mount is the swan (Hamsa), a bird revered in Indian mythology for its legendary 109‚Üí ability to separate milk from water ‚Äî symbolising the discrimination between truth and 110‚Üí falsehood, the essential from the superficial. This teaches us that true wisdom lies not 111‚Üí in accumulating information, but in the ability to discern what is meaningful. She is 112‚Üí sometimes also associated with the peacock, which represents the colourful beauty of the arts. 113‚Üí

114‚Üí 115‚Üí

Beyond Religion: A Universal Symbol

116‚Üí

117‚Üí Saraswati transcends religious boundaries. She is worshipped across Hinduism, Buddhism, 118‚Üí and Jainism as the patron of education, arts, and intellectual pursuit. In an age where 119‚Üí knowledge is humanity's greatest asset, Saraswati represents the eternal aspiration for 120‚Üí learning, creativity, and the illumination of the mind. She reminds us that true wealth 121‚Üí is not material but intellectual and spiritual ‚Äî and that this wealth, unlike material 122‚Üí possessions, grows when shared. 123‚Üí

220‚Üí

221‚Üí Saraswati Puja is celebrated on Basant Panchami, the fifth day of the Hindu month of Magha 222‚Üí (January-February), marking the arrival of spring. It is one of the most beloved festivals 223‚Üí for Bengali students and families. On this day, children dress in yellow (the colour of 224‚Üí spring and knowledge), books and instruments are placed before the goddess, and the 225‚Üí sacred ceremony of Hatey Khori is performed. 226‚Üí

227‚Üí

228‚Üí Hatey Khori (literally "chalk in hand") is a deeply moving tradition where young 229‚Üí children are introduced to the world of letters for the very first time. Seated before 230‚Üí the image of Saraswati, a child traces their first alphabet on a slate, guided by an 231‚Üí elder. This beautiful ritual symbolises the beginning of a lifelong journey of learning, 232‚Üí blessed by the Goddess of Knowledge herself. 233‚Üí

234‚Üí

235‚Üí At the Bengali Society of Melbourne, Saraswati Puja is a cherished annual celebration 236‚Üí where we honour academic excellence, nurture our children's connection to Bengali 237‚Üí culture, and celebrate the transformative power of education. It reminds our community 238‚Üí that wherever we are in the world, the pursuit of knowledge remains our highest calling. 239‚Üí

Goddess Saraswati: Divine Knowledge ‡¶¶‡ßá‡¶¨‡ßÄ ‡¶∏‡¶∞‡¶∏‡ßç‡¶¨‡¶§‡ßÄ: ‡¶¶‡¶ø‡¶¨‡ßç‡¶Ø ‡¶ú‡ßç‡¶û‡¶æ‡¶®‡ßá‡¶∞ ‡¶Ü‡¶≤‡ßã

The serene goddess of knowledge, music, arts, and wisdom

{/* The Story - Bilingual */}

The Goddess of Wisdom ‡¶¨‡¶ø‡¶¶‡ßç‡¶Ø‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶¶‡ßá‡¶¨‡ßÄ

{/* English Column */}
English

The River of Knowledge

Saraswati is one of the three great goddesses (Tridevi) of Hinduism, alongside Lakshmi and Parvati. Her name comes from the Sanskrit words "Sara" (essence) and "Swa" (self), meaning "the essence of the self". She is also named after the sacred Saraswati River, which in Vedic literature represents the flow of knowledge and wisdom. Just as a river nourishes the land through which it flows, Saraswati nourishes the mind with learning, creativity, and insight.

The Divine Iconography

Saraswati is depicted as an ethereally beautiful goddess dressed in pure white, symbolising the purity of true knowledge. She sits upon a white lotus, representing supreme reality and transcendence. In her four hands, she carries the sacred symbols of her domain:

  • The Veena ‚Äî a stringed musical instrument representing the arts, music, and the harmony of life. It teaches that knowledge must be tuned to produce sweetness, not discord.
  • The Vedas (sacred scriptures) ‚Äî representing universal, divine, and eternal knowledge that transcends all boundaries of time and place.
  • A Mala (rosary) ‚Äî symbolising the power of meditation, spiritual discipline, and inner contemplation.
  • A Kamandalu (water pot) ‚Äî representing the purifying power of knowledge that cleanses the mind of ignorance.

The Swan and the Peacock

Saraswati's mount is the swan (Hamsa), a bird revered in Indian mythology for its legendary ability to separate milk from water ‚Äî symbolising the discrimination between truth and falsehood, the essential from the superficial. This teaches us that true wisdom lies not in accumulating information, but in the ability to discern what is meaningful. She is sometimes also associated with the peacock, which represents the colourful beauty of the arts.

Beyond Religion: A Universal Symbol

Saraswati transcends religious boundaries. She is worshipped across Hinduism, Buddhism, and Jainism as the patron of education, arts, and intellectual pursuit. In an age where knowledge is humanity's greatest asset, Saraswati represents the eternal aspiration for learning, creativity, and the illumination of the mind. She reminds us that true wealth is not material but intellectual and spiritual ‚Äî and that this wealth, unlike material possessions, grows when shared.

Saraswati Puja in Bengali Culture ‡¶¨‡¶æ‡¶ô‡¶æ‡¶≤‡¶ø ‡¶∏‡¶Ç‡¶∏‡ßç‡¶ï‡ßÉ‡¶§‡¶ø‡¶§‡ßá ‡¶∏‡¶∞‡¶∏‡ßç‡¶¨‡¶§‡ßÄ ‡¶™‡ßÇ‡¶ú‡¶æ

English

Saraswati Puja is celebrated on Basant Panchami, the fifth day of the Hindu month of Magha (January-February), marking the arrival of spring. It is one of the most beloved festivals for Bengali students and families. On this day, children dress in yellow (the colour of spring and knowledge), books and instruments are placed before the goddess, and the sacred ceremony of Hatey Khori is performed.

Hatey Khori (literally "chalk in hand") is a deeply moving tradition where young children are introduced to the world of letters for the very first time. Seated before the image of Saraswati, a child traces their first alphabet on a slate, guided by an elder. This beautiful ritual symbolises the beginning of a lifelong journey of learning, blessed by the Goddess of Knowledge herself.

At the Bengali Society of Melbourne, Saraswati Puja is a cherished annual celebration where we honour academic excellence, nurture our children's connection to Bengali culture, and celebrate the transformative power of education. It reminds our community that wherever we are in the world, the pursuit of knowledge remains our highest calling.

83‚Üí

Born from Durga's Fury

84‚Üí

85‚Üí According to the Devi Mahatmyam, when the great demons Chanda and Munda attacked Goddess Durga 86‚Üí during her battle, the goddess grew so furious that her face turned dark as ink. From her furrowed 87‚Üí brow emerged Kali ‚Äî a terrifying figure with dark blue skin, wild dishevelled hair, a garland of 88‚Üí skulls around her neck, and a skirt of severed arms. She leapt onto the battlefield with a 89‚Üí fearsome roar, devouring the demon armies and slaying Chanda and Munda, earning the name Chamunda. 90‚Üí

91‚Üí 92‚Üí

The Destroyer of Evil

93‚Üí

94‚Üí Kali represents the most fierce aspect of the divine feminine ‚Äî Shakti in her most raw and 95‚Üí unbridled form. She is the destroyer of ego, ignorance, and evil. Her dark complexion symbolises 96‚Üí the infinite void from which all creation emerges and into which it dissolves. She is time itself 97‚Üí (her name derives from "Kala", meaning time), the force that consumes everything and 98‚Üí reminds us that nothing in this material world is permanent. 99‚Üí

100‚Üí 101‚Üí

The Sacred Symbolism

102‚Üí

103‚Üí Every aspect of Kali's fearsome appearance carries profound spiritual meaning. Her garland of 104‚Üí fifty skulls represents the fifty letters of the Sanskrit alphabet ‚Äî she is the mother of 105‚Üí language and knowledge. Her protruding tongue symbolises her consuming nature and also her 106‚Üí embarrassment at stepping on Lord Shiva. Her four arms represent the complete cycle of creation 107‚Üí and destruction: one hand holds a sword (the destroyer of false consciousness), another carries 108‚Üí a severed head (the ego), while the other two hands bless her devotees and dispel fear. 109‚Üí

110‚Üí 111‚Üí

Kali and Shiva

112‚Üí

113‚Üí One of the most iconic images in Hindu mythology is Kali standing atop a reclining Shiva. 114‚Üí After destroying the demons, Kali's bloodlust could not be contained and she began her dance 115‚Üí of destruction, threatening to annihilate the entire cosmos. To stop her, Shiva lay down 116‚Üí beneath her feet. When Kali stepped on her husband, she was struck with shame and thrust 117‚Üí out her tongue in surprise. This image teaches us that Shakti (energy) without Shiva 118‚Üí (consciousness) becomes destructive, and Shiva without Shakti is inert ‚Äî they are 119‚Üí inseparable and interdependent. 120‚Üí

121‚Üí 122‚Üí

The Compassionate Mother

123‚Üí

124‚Üí Beneath her fearsome exterior, Kali is the most loving and protective of all mothers. She 125‚Üí destroys only that which threatens her children ‚Äî evil, ignorance, and suffering. Devotees 126‚Üí of Kali, particularly in Bengal, relate to her not with fear but with the intimate love of 127‚Üí a child for their mother. The great saint Ramakrishna Paramahansa worshipped Kali as his 128‚Üí divine mother at the Dakshineswar temple, experiencing her as a boundlessly compassionate 129‚Üí presence. To Bengalis, she is simply "Ma" ‚Äî the Mother who fiercely protects and tenderly loves. 130‚Üí

236‚Üí Kali Puja, celebrated on the new moon night of Kartik (October-November), coincides with 237‚Üí Deepavali across India but holds a uniquely Bengali character. While the rest of India 238‚Üí celebrates with Lakshmi Puja and fireworks, Bengal worships Kali with deep devotion, 239‚Üí elaborate night-long rituals, and stunning illuminated pandals. 240‚Üí

241‚Üí

242‚Üí The festival is observed on the darkest night of the year, symbolising Kali's power to 243‚Üí bring light into darkness. Homes and temples are lit with countless oil lamps and candles, 244‚Üí representing the triumph of knowledge over ignorance and hope over despair. It is a night 245‚Üí of profound spiritual significance and joyous community celebration. 246‚Üí

247‚Üí

248‚Üí At BSM, our Kali Puja and Deepavali celebration brings the Bengali community together 249‚Üí for an evening of traditional puja, cultural performances, and festive togetherness, 250‚Üí keeping the spirit of this unique Bengali tradition alive in Melbourne. 251‚Üí

Kali Mata: The Dark Mother ‡¶ï‡¶æ‡¶≤‡ßÄ ‡¶Æ‡¶æ‡¶§‡¶æ: ‡¶§‡¶Æ‡¶∏‡¶æ‡¶®‡¶æ‡¶∂‡¶ø‡¶®‡ßÄ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡¶®‡ßÄ

The fierce protector and compassionate mother of the universe

{/* The Story - Bilingual */}

The Origin & Mythology ‡¶â‡ßé‡¶™‡¶§‡ßç‡¶§‡¶ø ‡¶ì ‡¶™‡ßå‡¶∞‡¶æ‡¶£‡¶ø‡¶ï ‡¶ï‡¶æ‡¶π‡¶ø‡¶®‡ßÄ

{/* English Column */}
English

Born from Durga's Fury

According to the Devi Mahatmyam, when the great demons Chanda and Munda attacked Goddess Durga during her battle, the goddess grew so furious that her face turned dark as ink. From her furrowed brow emerged Kali ‚Äî a terrifying figure with dark blue skin, wild dishevelled hair, a garland of skulls around her neck, and a skirt of severed arms. She leapt onto the battlefield with a fearsome roar, devouring the demon armies and slaying Chanda and Munda, earning the name Chamunda.

The Destroyer of Evil

Kali represents the most fierce aspect of the divine feminine ‚Äî Shakti in her most raw and unbridled form. She is the destroyer of ego, ignorance, and evil. Her dark complexion symbolises the infinite void from which all creation emerges and into which it dissolves. She is time itself (her name derives from "Kala", meaning time), the force that consumes everything and reminds us that nothing in this material world is permanent.

The Sacred Symbolism

Every aspect of Kali's fearsome appearance carries profound spiritual meaning. Her garland of fifty skulls represents the fifty letters of the Sanskrit alphabet ‚Äî she is the mother of language and knowledge. Her protruding tongue symbolises her consuming nature and also her embarrassment at stepping on Lord Shiva. Her four arms represent the complete cycle of creation and destruction: one hand holds a sword (the destroyer of false consciousness), another carries a severed head (the ego), while the other two hands bless her devotees and dispel fear.

Kali and Shiva

One of the most iconic images in Hindu mythology is Kali standing atop a reclining Shiva. After destroying the demons, Kali's bloodlust could not be contained and she began her dance of destruction, threatening to annihilate the entire cosmos. To stop her, Shiva lay down beneath her feet. When Kali stepped on her husband, she was struck with shame and thrust out her tongue in surprise. This image teaches us that Shakti (energy) without Shiva (consciousness) becomes destructive, and Shiva without Shakti is inert ‚Äî they are inseparable and interdependent.

The Compassionate Mother

Beneath her fearsome exterior, Kali is the most loving and protective of all mothers. She destroys only that which threatens her children ‚Äî evil, ignorance, and suffering. Devotees of Kali, particularly in Bengal, relate to her not with fear but with the intimate love of a child for their mother. The great saint Ramakrishna Paramahansa worshipped Kali as his divine mother at the Dakshineswar temple, experiencing her as a boundlessly compassionate presence. To Bengalis, she is simply "Ma" ‚Äî the Mother who fiercely protects and tenderly loves.

Kali Puja in Bengali Culture ‡¶¨‡¶æ‡¶ô‡¶æ‡¶≤‡¶ø ‡¶∏‡¶Ç‡¶∏‡ßç‡¶ï‡ßÉ‡¶§‡¶ø‡¶§‡ßá ‡¶ï‡¶æ‡¶≤‡ßÄ‡¶™‡ßÇ‡¶ú‡¶æ

English

Kali Puja, celebrated on the new moon night of Kartik (October-November), coincides with Deepavali across India but holds a uniquely Bengali character. While the rest of India celebrates with Lakshmi Puja and fireworks, Bengal worships Kali with deep devotion, elaborate night-long rituals, and stunning illuminated pandals.

The festival is observed on the darkest night of the year, symbolising Kali's power to bring light into darkness. Homes and temples are lit with countless oil lamps and candles, representing the triumph of knowledge over ignorance and hope over despair. It is a night of profound spiritual significance and joyous community celebration.

At BSM, our Kali Puja and Deepavali celebration brings the Bengali community together for an evening of traditional puja, cultural performances, and festive togetherness, keeping the spirit of this unique Bengali tradition alive in Melbourne.

Now I have a complete understanding of the codebase. Let me create the feature branch and start implementing. I have all the information I need.

Let me plan the implementation order:
1. Create feature branch
2. Create `storyData.ts` with types, 12 story metadata, 3 article metadata, helpers
3. Create `StoryPageLayout.tsx` shared layout component
4. Create `stories/page.tsx` combined listing
5. Move 3 article pages to stories/, update internal links
6. Delete articles/ directory
7. Create 12 children's story pages
8. Update Header.tsx, Footer.tsx, sitemap.ts


9. Build and verify everything works

This is a large implementation, so I'll structure it efficiently: start with the feature branch and foundational files like storyData.ts and the shared layout component, then create the combined listing page, move the existing articles over while updating their links, generate all 12 story pages, and finally update the navigation and sitemap before testing the build.

// Helpers
export function getStoriesByDeity(deity: Story['deity']): Story[] {
  return childrenStories.filter((s) => s.deity === deity)
}

export function getAllContent(): Story[] {
  return [...childrenStories, ...articles]
}

export function getStoryBySlug(slug: string): Story | undefined {
  return childrenStories.find((s) => s.slug === slug)
}

export function getRelatedStories(story: Story): Story[] {
  return childrenStories.filter((s) => s.deity === story.deity && s.slug !== story.slug)
}

export function getAdjacentStories(slug: string): { prev: Story | null; next: Story | null } {
  const idx = childrenStories.findIndex((s) => s.slug === slug)
  return {
    prev: idx > 0 ? childrenStories[idx - 1] : null,
    next: idx < childrenStories.length - 1 ? childrenStories[idx + 1] : null,
  }
}

He prayed for years and years to Lord Brahma, sitting perfectly still through scorching summers and freezing winters. Impressed by his devotion, Brahma appeared and granted him a wish.         content: "On Mount Kailash, in the divine household of Shiva and Parvati, a problem arose that every family can understand: both sons wanted to get married, and both thought they should go first!\n\nKartikeya, the handsome warrior, said: \"I am the firstborn! I should naturally marry first.\" (In some versions of the story, Kartikeya is the elder, in others Ganesh is ‚Äî the gods themselves seem to disagree on this!)\n\nGanesh, the wise elephant-headed brother, said: \"Age is just a number, brother. What matters is who is more deserving.\"\n\nShiva and Parvati sighed ‚Äî this argument had been going on for days. Finally, Shiva proposed the same challenge as before: \"Race around the world.         bengaliCallout: '"‡¶Ü‡¶Æ‡¶ø ‡¶Ü‡¶ó‡ßá!" "‡¶®‡¶æ, ‡¶Ü‡¶Æ‡¶ø ‡¶Ü‡¶ó‡ßá!" ‚Äî ‡¶∂‡¶ø‡¶¨ ‡¶Ü‡¶∞ ‡¶™‡¶æ‡¶∞‡ßç‡¶¨‡¶§‡ßÄ ‡¶¶‡ßÅ‡¶á ‡¶õ‡ßá‡¶≤‡ßá‡¶∞ ‡¶ù‡¶ó‡¶°‡¶º‡¶æ‡¶Ø‡¶º ‡¶ï‡ßç‡¶≤‡¶æ‡¶®‡ßç‡¶§ ‡¶π‡¶Ø‡¶º‡ßá ‡¶™‡ßç‡¶∞‡¶§‡¶ø‡¶Ø‡ßã‡¶ó‡¶ø‡¶§‡¶æ ‡¶¶‡¶ø‡¶≤‡ßá‡¶®!',

        titleBengali: '‡¶Ü‡¶¨‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶¶‡ßå‡¶°‡¶º ‡¶∂‡ßÅ‡¶∞‡ßÅ',
        content: "Once again, Kartikeya shot off on his peacock like a streak of blue-green lightning. He had learned nothing from the mango incident ‚Äî or perhaps he thought the same trick wouldn't work twice.\n\nGanesh watched his brother disappear into the horizon, then calmly turned to his parents. \"The scriptures say that one's parents are the whole world,\" he said. And once again, he walked around Shiva and Parvati three times with loving devotion.\n\nBut this time there was a twist. When Ganesh completed his circumambulation of his parents, Shiva declared him the winner ‚Äî and his marriage to Siddhi and Buddhi was performed right there and then!",
        bengaliCallout: '‡¶ó‡¶£‡ßá‡¶∂ ‡¶Ü‡¶¨‡¶æ‡¶∞‡¶ì ‡¶Æ‡¶æ-‡¶¨‡¶æ‡¶¨‡¶æ‡¶ï‡ßá ‡¶™‡ßç‡¶∞‡¶¶‡¶ï‡ßç‡¶∑‡¶ø‡¶£ ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶≤‡ßá‡¶® ‚Äî ‡¶è‡¶¨‡¶Ç ‡¶è‡¶¨‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶™‡ßÅ‡¶∞‡¶∏‡ßç‡¶ï‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶õ‡¶ø‡¶≤ ‡¶∏‡¶ø‡¶¶‡ßç‡¶ß‡¶ø ‡¶ì ‡¶¨‡ßÅ‡¶¶‡ßç‡¶ß‡¶ø‡¶∞ ‡¶∏‡¶æ‡¶•‡ßá ‡¶¨‡¶ø‡¶¨‡¶æ‡¶π!',

He flew south to a mountain called Palani (in what is now Tamil Nadu in southern India) and declared that he would live there alone, away from his family. He shaved his head and gave up all his royal possessions.\n\nWhen Parvati heard this, her heart broke. She rushed to see her son.",

        content: "Parvati found Kartikeya on his lonely mountain. \"My son,\" she said gently, \"your anger is understandable. You feel it was unfair. But think about it ‚Äî Ganesh's wisdom and your strength are both needed in this world. He won with cleverness; you would win in any test of courage or battle. You are both special in different ways.\"\n\nKartikeya looked at his mother and felt his anger melting. She was right. // Helpers
export function getStoriesByDeity(deity: Story['deity']): Story[] {
  return childrenStories.filter((s) => s.deity === deity)
}

export function getAllContent(): Story[] {
  return [...childrenStories, ...articles]
}

export function getStoryBySlug(slug: string): Story | undefined {
  return childrenStories.find((s) => s.slug === slug)
}

export function getRelatedStories(story: Story): Story[] {
  return childrenStories.filter((s) => s.deity === story.deity && s.slug !== story.slug)
}

export function getAdjacentStories(slug: string): { prev: Story | null; next: Story | null } {
  const idx = childrenStories.findIndex((s) => s.slug === slug)
  return {
    prev: idx > 0 ? childrenStories[idx - 1] : null,
    next: idx < childrenStories.length - 1 ? childrenStories[idx + 1] : null,
  }
}

The Legend of Durga Slaying Mahishasura ‡¶¶‡ßÅ‡¶∞‡ßç‡¶ó‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶Æ‡¶π‡¶ø‡¶∑‡¶æ‡¶∏‡ßÅ‡¶∞ ‡¶¨‡¶ß‡ßá‡¶∞ ‡¶ï‡¶æ‡¶π‡¶ø‡¶®‡ßÄ

The epic tale of good triumphing over evil

{/* The Story - Bilingual */}

The Story ‡¶ï‡¶æ‡¶π‡¶ø‡¶®‡ßÄ

{/* English Column */}
English

The Tyranny of Mahishasura

Long ago, the demon Mahishasura ‚Äî the buffalo demon ‚Äî performed severe penance to please Lord Brahma. Impressed by his devotion, Brahma granted him a boon: no god or demon could ever kill him. Emboldened by this near-invincibility, Mahishasura waged war against the Devas (gods) and drove them out of heaven. He terrorised the three worlds ‚Äî heaven, earth, and the netherworld ‚Äî plunging all of creation into darkness and suffering.

The Birth of Goddess Durga

The defeated gods turned to the holy trinity ‚Äî Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva ‚Äî for help. In their fury at Mahishasura's atrocities, all the gods combined their divine energies. From this blazing convergence of cosmic power, a radiant female form emerged ‚Äî Goddess Durga, the embodiment of Shakti (divine feminine energy). She was more powerful than any single deity, for she carried the collective strength of all the gods within her.

The Ten Arms and Divine Weapons

Each god bestowed upon Durga their most powerful weapon. Shiva gave her his trident (trishul), Vishnu his discus (sudarshana chakra), Indra his thunderbolt (vajra), Vayu gave his bow and arrows, and Himavan gifted her a magnificent lion as her mount. With ten arms, each wielding a divine weapon, Durga was the ultimate warrior ‚Äî beautiful yet fearsome, serene yet invincible. Her very form symbolised the truth that when all righteous forces unite, no evil can withstand them.

The Great Battle

The battle between Durga and Mahishasura raged for nine days and nine nights. The demon king changed his form repeatedly ‚Äî appearing as a buffalo, a lion, an elephant, and a warrior ‚Äî trying every trick to overpower the goddess. But Durga matched him at every turn, her divine weapons countering each transformation. The earth trembled, the seas roared, and the skies blazed with the fury of their combat.

The Victory ‚Äî Vijaya Dashami

On the tenth day, as Mahishasura assumed his buffalo form once more, Durga leapt upon him, pinning him with her foot. She drove her trident through his chest, and the great demon fell. The heavens erupted in celebration. The gods showered flowers from the sky, and the three worlds rejoiced. This day of triumph is celebrated as Vijaya Dashami (Dashami meaning the tenth day), the culmination of Durga Puja. It represents the eternal promise that righteousness will always prevail over evil, no matter how powerful the darkness may seem.

{/* Significance Section */}

Why We Celebrate ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶® ‡¶Ü‡¶Æ‡¶∞‡¶æ ‡¶â‡¶¶‡¶Ø‡¶æ‡¶™‡¶® ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶ø

English

Durga Puja is the grandest festival for Bengalis worldwide. For five days each autumn, communities come together to honour the Goddess through elaborate rituals, stunning pandal decorations, cultural performances, and communal feasting. It is more than a religious observance ‚Äî it is a celebration of art, community, homecoming, and the enduring human belief in the triumph of good over evil.

At the Bengali Society of Melbourne, Durgotsav is our most anticipated annual event. It brings together Bengali families from across Victoria, recreating the warmth and spirit of celebrations back home. From the rhythmic beats of the dhak to the fragrance of dhunuchi, every element connects us to our heritage and to each other.

The Legend of Durga Slaying Mahishasura ‡¶¶‡ßÅ‡¶∞‡ßç‡¶ó‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶Æ‡¶π‡¶ø‡¶∑‡¶æ‡¶∏‡ßÅ‡¶∞ ‡¶¨‡¶ß‡ßá‡¶∞ ‡¶ï‡¶æ‡¶π‡¶ø‡¶®‡ßÄ

The epic tale of good triumphing over evil

{/* The Story - Bilingual */}

The Story ‡¶ï‡¶æ‡¶π‡¶ø‡¶®‡ßÄ

{/* English Column */}
English

The Tyranny of Mahishasura

Long ago, the demon Mahishasura ‚Äî the buffalo demon ‚Äî performed severe penance to please Lord Brahma. Impressed by his devotion, Brahma granted him a boon: no god or demon could ever kill him. Emboldened by this near-invincibility, Mahishasura waged war against the Devas (gods) and drove them out of heaven. He terrorised the three worlds ‚Äî heaven, earth, and the netherworld ‚Äî plunging all of creation into darkness and suffering.

The Birth of Goddess Durga

The defeated gods turned to the holy trinity ‚Äî Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva ‚Äî for help. In their fury at Mahishasura's atrocities, all the gods combined their divine energies. From this blazing convergence of cosmic power, a radiant female form emerged ‚Äî Goddess Durga, the embodiment of Shakti (divine feminine energy). She was more powerful than any single deity, for she carried the collective strength of all the gods within her.

The Ten Arms and Divine Weapons

Each god bestowed upon Durga their most powerful weapon. Shiva gave her his trident (trishul), Vishnu his discus (sudarshana chakra), Indra his thunderbolt (vajra), Vayu gave his bow and arrows, and Himavan gifted her a magnificent lion as her mount. With ten arms, each wielding a divine weapon, Durga was the ultimate warrior ‚Äî beautiful yet fearsome, serene yet invincible. Her very form symbolised the truth that when all righteous forces unite, no evil can withstand them.

The Great Battle

The battle between Durga and Mahishasura raged for nine days and nine nights. The demon king changed his form repeatedly ‚Äî appearing as a buffalo, a lion, an elephant, and a warrior ‚Äî trying every trick to overpower the goddess. But Durga matched him at every turn, her divine weapons countering each transformation. The earth trembled, the seas roared, and the skies blazed with the fury of their combat.

The Victory ‚Äî Vijaya Dashami

On the tenth day, as Mahishasura assumed his buffalo form once more, Durga leapt upon him, pinning him with her foot. She drove her trident through his chest, and the great demon fell. The heavens erupted in celebration. The gods showered flowers from the sky, and the three worlds rejoiced. This day of triumph is celebrated as Vijaya Dashami (Dashami meaning the tenth day), the culmination of Durga Puja. It represents the eternal promise that righteousness will always prevail over evil, no matter how powerful the darkness may seem.

Why We Celebrate ‡¶ï‡ßá‡¶® ‡¶Ü‡¶Æ‡¶∞‡¶æ ‡¶â‡¶¶‡¶Ø‡¶æ‡¶™‡¶® ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶ø

English

Durga Puja is the grandest festival for Bengalis worldwide. For five days each autumn, communities come together to honour the Goddess through elaborate rituals, stunning pandal decorations, cultural performances, and communal feasting. It is more than a religious observance ‚Äî it is a celebration of art, community, homecoming, and the enduring human belief in the triumph of good over evil.

At the Bengali Society of Melbourne, Durgotsav is our most anticipated annual event. It brings together Bengali families from across Victoria, recreating the warmth and spirit of celebrations back home. From the rhythmic beats of the dhak to the fragrance of dhunuchi, every element connects us to our heritage and to each other.

Goddess Saraswati: Divine Knowledge ‡¶¶‡ßá‡¶¨‡ßÄ ‡¶∏‡¶∞‡¶∏‡ßç‡¶¨‡¶§‡ßÄ: ‡¶¶‡¶ø‡¶¨‡ßç‡¶Ø ‡¶ú‡ßç‡¶û‡¶æ‡¶®‡ßá‡¶∞ ‡¶Ü‡¶≤‡ßã

The serene goddess of knowledge, music, arts, and wisdom

{/* The Story - Bilingual */}

The Goddess of Wisdom ‡¶¨‡¶ø‡¶¶‡ßç‡¶Ø‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶¶‡ßá‡¶¨‡ßÄ

{/* English Column */}
English

The River of Knowledge

Saraswati is one of the three great goddesses (Tridevi) of Hinduism, alongside Lakshmi and Parvati. Her name comes from the Sanskrit words "Sara" (essence) and "Swa" (self), meaning "the essence of the self". She is also named after the sacred Saraswati River, which in Vedic literature represents the flow of knowledge and wisdom. Just as a river nourishes the land through which it flows, Saraswati nourishes the mind with learning, creativity, and insight.

The Divine Iconography

Saraswati is depicted as an ethereally beautiful goddess dressed in pure white, symbolising the purity of true knowledge. She sits upon a white lotus, representing supreme reality and transcendence. In her four hands, she carries the sacred symbols of her domain:

  • The Veena ‚Äî a stringed musical instrument representing the arts, music, and the harmony of life. It teaches that knowledge must be tuned to produce sweetness, not discord.
  • The Vedas (sacred scriptures) ‚Äî representing universal, divine, and eternal knowledge that transcends all boundaries of time and place.
  • A Mala (rosary) ‚Äî symbolising the power of meditation, spiritual discipline, and inner contemplation.
  • A Kamandalu (water pot) ‚Äî representing the purifying power of knowledge that cleanses the mind of ignorance.

The Swan and the Peacock

Saraswati's mount is the swan (Hamsa), a bird revered in Indian mythology for its legendary ability to separate milk from water ‚Äî symbolising the discrimination between truth and falsehood, the essential from the superficial. This teaches us that true wisdom lies not in accumulating information, but in the ability to discern what is meaningful. She is sometimes also associated with the peacock, which represents the colourful beauty of the arts.

Beyond Religion: A Universal Symbol

Saraswati transcends religious boundaries. She is worshipped across Hinduism, Buddhism, and Jainism as the patron of education, arts, and intellectual pursuit. In an age where knowledge is humanity's greatest asset, Saraswati represents the eternal aspiration for learning, creativity, and the illumination of the mind. She reminds us that true wealth is not material but intellectual and spiritual ‚Äî and that this wealth, unlike material possessions, grows when shared.

Saraswati Puja in Bengali Culture ‡¶¨‡¶æ‡¶ô‡¶æ‡¶≤‡¶ø ‡¶∏‡¶Ç‡¶∏‡ßç‡¶ï‡ßÉ‡¶§‡¶ø‡¶§‡ßá ‡¶∏‡¶∞‡¶∏‡ßç‡¶¨‡¶§‡ßÄ ‡¶™‡ßÇ‡¶ú‡¶æ

English

Saraswati Puja is celebrated on Basant Panchami, the fifth day of the Hindu month of Magha (January-February), marking the arrival of spring. It is one of the most beloved festivals for Bengali students and families. On this day, children dress in yellow (the colour of spring and knowledge), books and instruments are placed before the goddess, and the sacred ceremony of Hatey Khori is performed.

Hatey Khori (literally "chalk in hand") is a deeply moving tradition where young children are introduced to the world of letters for the very first time. Seated before the image of Saraswati, a child traces their first alphabet on a slate, guided by an elder. This beautiful ritual symbolises the beginning of a lifelong journey of learning, blessed by the Goddess of Knowledge herself.

At the Bengali Society of Melbourne, Saraswati Puja is a cherished annual celebration where we honour academic excellence, nurture our children's connection to Bengali culture, and celebrate the transformative power of education. It reminds our community that wherever we are in the world, the pursuit of knowledge remains our highest calling.

Goddess Saraswati: Divine Knowledge ‡¶¶‡ßá‡¶¨‡ßÄ ‡¶∏‡¶∞‡¶∏‡ßç‡¶¨‡¶§‡ßÄ: ‡¶¶‡¶ø‡¶¨‡ßç‡¶Ø ‡¶ú‡ßç‡¶û‡¶æ‡¶®‡ßá‡¶∞ ‡¶Ü‡¶≤‡ßã

The serene goddess of knowledge, music, arts, and wisdom

{/* The Story - Bilingual */}

The Goddess of Wisdom ‡¶¨‡¶ø‡¶¶‡ßç‡¶Ø‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶¶‡ßá‡¶¨‡ßÄ

{/* English Column */}
English

The River of Knowledge

Saraswati is one of the three great goddesses (Tridevi) of Hinduism, alongside Lakshmi and Parvati. Her name comes from the Sanskrit words "Sara" (essence) and "Swa" (self), meaning "the essence of the self". She is also named after the sacred Saraswati River, which in Vedic literature represents the flow of knowledge and wisdom. Just as a river nourishes the land through which it flows, Saraswati nourishes the mind with learning, creativity, and insight.

The Divine Iconography

Saraswati is depicted as an ethereally beautiful goddess dressed in pure white, symbolising the purity of true knowledge. She sits upon a white lotus, representing supreme reality and transcendence. In her four hands, she carries the sacred symbols of her domain:

  • The Veena ‚Äî a stringed musical instrument representing the arts, music, and the harmony of life. It teaches that knowledge must be tuned to produce sweetness, not discord.
  • The Vedas (sacred scriptures) ‚Äî representing universal, divine, and eternal knowledge that transcends all boundaries of time and place.
  • A Mala (rosary) ‚Äî symbolising the power of meditation, spiritual discipline, and inner contemplation.
  • A Kamandalu (water pot) ‚Äî representing the purifying power of knowledge that cleanses the mind of ignorance.

The Swan and the Peacock

Saraswati's mount is the swan (Hamsa), a bird revered in Indian mythology for its legendary ability to separate milk from water ‚Äî symbolising the discrimination between truth and falsehood, the essential from the superficial. This teaches us that true wisdom lies not in accumulating information, but in the ability to discern what is meaningful. She is sometimes also associated with the peacock, which represents the colourful beauty of the arts.

Beyond Religion: A Universal Symbol

Saraswati transcends religious boundaries. She is worshipped across Hinduism, Buddhism, and Jainism as the patron of education, arts, and intellectual pursuit. In an age where knowledge is humanity's greatest asset, Saraswati represents the eternal aspiration for learning, creativity, and the illumination of the mind. She reminds us that true wealth is not material but intellectual and spiritual ‚Äî and that this wealth, unlike material possessions, grows when shared.

Saraswati Puja in Bengali Culture ‡¶¨‡¶æ‡¶ô‡¶æ‡¶≤‡¶ø ‡¶∏‡¶Ç‡¶∏‡ßç‡¶ï‡ßÉ‡¶§‡¶ø‡¶§‡ßá ‡¶∏‡¶∞‡¶∏‡ßç‡¶¨‡¶§‡ßÄ ‡¶™‡ßÇ‡¶ú‡¶æ

English

Saraswati Puja is celebrated on Basant Panchami, the fifth day of the Hindu month of Magha (January-February), marking the arrival of spring. It is one of the most beloved festivals for Bengali students and families. On this day, children dress in yellow (the colour of spring and knowledge), books and instruments are placed before the goddess, and the sacred ceremony of Hatey Khori is performed.

Hatey Khori (literally "chalk in hand") is a deeply moving tradition where young children are introduced to the world of letters for the very first time. Seated before the image of Saraswati, a child traces their first alphabet on a slate, guided by an elder. This beautiful ritual symbolises the beginning of a lifelong journey of learning, blessed by the Goddess of Knowledge herself.

At the Bengali Society of Melbourne, Saraswati Puja is a cherished annual celebration where we honour academic excellence, nurture our children's connection to Bengali culture, and celebrate the transformative power of education. It reminds our community that wherever we are in the world, the pursuit of knowledge remains our highest calling.

Kali Mata: The Dark Mother ‡¶ï‡¶æ‡¶≤‡ßÄ ‡¶Æ‡¶æ‡¶§‡¶æ: ‡¶§‡¶Æ‡¶∏‡¶æ‡¶®‡¶æ‡¶∂‡¶ø‡¶®‡ßÄ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡¶®‡ßÄ

The fierce protector and compassionate mother of the universe

{/* The Story - Bilingual */}

The Origin & Mythology ‡¶â‡ßé‡¶™‡¶§‡ßç‡¶§‡¶ø ‡¶ì ‡¶™‡ßå‡¶∞‡¶æ‡¶£‡¶ø‡¶ï ‡¶ï‡¶æ‡¶π‡¶ø‡¶®‡ßÄ

{/* English Column */}
English

Born from Durga's Fury

According to the Devi Mahatmyam, when the great demons Chanda and Munda attacked Goddess Durga during her battle, the goddess grew so furious that her face turned dark as ink. From her furrowed brow emerged Kali ‚Äî a terrifying figure with dark blue skin, wild dishevelled hair, a garland of skulls around her neck, and a skirt of severed arms. She leapt onto the battlefield with a fearsome roar, devouring the demon armies and slaying Chanda and Munda, earning the name Chamunda.

The Destroyer of Evil

Kali represents the most fierce aspect of the divine feminine ‚Äî Shakti in her most raw and unbridled form. She is the destroyer of ego, ignorance, and evil. Her dark complexion symbolises the infinite void from which all creation emerges and into which it dissolves. She is time itself (her name derives from "Kala", meaning time), the force that consumes everything and reminds us that nothing in this material world is permanent.

The Sacred Symbolism

Every aspect of Kali's fearsome appearance carries profound spiritual meaning. Her garland of fifty skulls represents the fifty letters of the Sanskrit alphabet ‚Äî she is the mother of language and knowledge. Her protruding tongue symbolises her consuming nature and also her embarrassment at stepping on Lord Shiva. Her four arms represent the complete cycle of creation and destruction: one hand holds a sword (the destroyer of false consciousness), another carries a severed head (the ego), while the other two hands bless her devotees and dispel fear.

Kali and Shiva

One of the most iconic images in Hindu mythology is Kali standing atop a reclining Shiva. After destroying the demons, Kali's bloodlust could not be contained and she began her dance of destruction, threatening to annihilate the entire cosmos. To stop her, Shiva lay down beneath her feet. When Kali stepped on her husband, she was struck with shame and thrust out her tongue in surprise. This image teaches us that Shakti (energy) without Shiva (consciousness) becomes destructive, and Shiva without Shakti is inert ‚Äî they are inseparable and interdependent.

The Compassionate Mother

Beneath her fearsome exterior, Kali is the most loving and protective of all mothers. She destroys only that which threatens her children ‚Äî evil, ignorance, and suffering. Devotees of Kali, particularly in Bengal, relate to her not with fear but with the intimate love of a child for their mother. The great saint Ramakrishna Paramahansa worshipped Kali as his divine mother at the Dakshineswar temple, experiencing her as a boundlessly compassionate presence. To Bengalis, she is simply "Ma" ‚Äî the Mother who fiercely protects and tenderly loves.

Kali Puja in Bengali Culture ‡¶¨‡¶æ‡¶ô‡¶æ‡¶≤‡¶ø ‡¶∏‡¶Ç‡¶∏‡ßç‡¶ï‡ßÉ‡¶§‡¶ø‡¶§‡ßá ‡¶ï‡¶æ‡¶≤‡ßÄ‡¶™‡ßÇ‡¶ú‡¶æ

English

Kali Puja, celebrated on the new moon night of Kartik (October-November), coincides with Deepavali across India but holds a uniquely Bengali character. While the rest of India celebrates with Lakshmi Puja and fireworks, Bengal worships Kali with deep devotion, elaborate night-long rituals, and stunning illuminated pandals.

The festival is observed on the darkest night of the year, symbolising Kali's power to bring light into darkness. Homes and temples are lit with countless oil lamps and candles, representing the triumph of knowledge over ignorance and hope over despair. It is a night of profound spiritual significance and joyous community celebration.

At BSM, our Kali Puja and Deepavali celebration brings the Bengali community together for an evening of traditional puja, cultural performances, and festive togetherness, keeping the spirit of this unique Bengali tradition alive in Melbourne.

Kali Mata: The Dark Mother ‡¶ï‡¶æ‡¶≤‡ßÄ ‡¶Æ‡¶æ‡¶§‡¶æ: ‡¶§‡¶Æ‡¶∏‡¶æ‡¶®‡¶æ‡¶∂‡¶ø‡¶®‡ßÄ ‡¶ú‡¶®‡¶®‡ßÄ

The fierce protector and compassionate mother of the universe

{/* The Story - Bilingual */}

The Origin & Mythology ‡¶â‡ßé‡¶™‡¶§‡ßç‡¶§‡¶ø ‡¶ì ‡¶™‡ßå‡¶∞‡¶æ‡¶£‡¶ø‡¶ï ‡¶ï‡¶æ‡¶π‡¶ø‡¶®‡ßÄ

{/* English Column */}
English

Born from Durga's Fury

According to the Devi Mahatmyam, when the great demons Chanda and Munda attacked Goddess Durga during her battle, the goddess grew so furious that her face turned dark as ink. From her furrowed brow emerged Kali ‚Äî a terrifying figure with dark blue skin, wild dishevelled hair, a garland of skulls around her neck, and a skirt of severed arms. She leapt onto the battlefield with a fearsome roar, devouring the demon armies and slaying Chanda and Munda, earning the name Chamunda.

The Destroyer of Evil

Kali represents the most fierce aspect of the divine feminine ‚Äî Shakti in her most raw and unbridled form. She is the destroyer of ego, ignorance, and evil. Her dark complexion symbolises the infinite void from which all creation emerges and into which it dissolves. She is time itself (her name derives from "Kala", meaning time), the force that consumes everything and reminds us that nothing in this material world is permanent.

The Sacred Symbolism

Every aspect of Kali's fearsome appearance carries profound spiritual meaning. Her garland of fifty skulls represents the fifty letters of the Sanskrit alphabet ‚Äî she is the mother of language and knowledge. Her protruding tongue symbolises her consuming nature and also her embarrassment at stepping on Lord Shiva. Her four arms represent the complete cycle of creation and destruction: one hand holds a sword (the destroyer of false consciousness), another carries a severed head (the ego), while the other two hands bless her devotees and dispel fear.

Kali and Shiva

One of the most iconic images in Hindu mythology is Kali standing atop a reclining Shiva. After destroying the demons, Kali's bloodlust could not be contained and she began her dance of destruction, threatening to annihilate the entire cosmos. To stop her, Shiva lay down beneath her feet. When Kali stepped on her husband, she was struck with shame and thrust out her tongue in surprise. This image teaches us that Shakti (energy) without Shiva (consciousness) becomes destructive, and Shiva without Shakti is inert ‚Äî they are inseparable and interdependent.

The Compassionate Mother

Beneath her fearsome exterior, Kali is the most loving and protective of all mothers. She destroys only that which threatens her children ‚Äî evil, ignorance, and suffering. Devotees of Kali, particularly in Bengal, relate to her not with fear but with the intimate love of a child for their mother. The great saint Ramakrishna Paramahansa worshipped Kali as his divine mother at the Dakshineswar temple, experiencing her as a boundlessly compassionate presence. To Bengalis, she is simply "Ma" ‚Äî the Mother who fiercely protects and tenderly loves.

Kali Puja in Bengali Culture ‡¶¨‡¶æ‡¶ô‡¶æ‡¶≤‡¶ø ‡¶∏‡¶Ç‡¶∏‡ßç‡¶ï‡ßÉ‡¶§‡¶ø‡¶§‡ßá ‡¶ï‡¶æ‡¶≤‡ßÄ‡¶™‡ßÇ‡¶ú‡¶æ

English

Kali Puja, celebrated on the new moon night of Kartik (October-November), coincides with Deepavali across India but holds a uniquely Bengali character. While the rest of India celebrates with Lakshmi Puja and fireworks, Bengal worships Kali with deep devotion, elaborate night-long rituals, and stunning illuminated pandals.

The festival is observed on the darkest night of the year, symbolising Kali's power to bring light into darkness. Homes and temples are lit with countless oil lamps and candles, representing the triumph of knowledge over ignorance and hope over despair. It is a night of profound spiritual significance and joyous community celebration.

At BSM, our Kali Puja and Deepavali celebration brings the Bengali community together for an evening of traditional puja, cultural performances, and festive togetherness, keeping the spirit of this unique Bengali tradition alive in Melbourne.

'use client'

import Link from 'next/link'
import Image from 'next/image'

Implementation is complete. Here's a summary of everything done:

**Files created (15 new):**
- `frontend/src/app/stories/storyData.ts` ‚Äî Types, 12 children's story metadata (with full narrative content), 3 article metadata, helpers
- `frontend/src/components/StoryPageLayout.tsx` ‚Äî Shared layout for children's story pages (hero, sections, Bengali callouts, moral, related stories, prev/next nav)
- `frontend/src/app/stories/page.tsx` ‚Äî Combined listing with children's stories by deity (top) + articles (bottom)
- 12 individual story pages: `mahishasur-bodh`, `umar-agomoni`, `durgar-dosh-ostro`, `saraswatir-binadan`, `hatekhari`, `saraswati-o-ondhokar`, `ganesher-gajanon`, `prithivi-prodokshin`, `ganesher-mahabharot-lekha`, `kartikayer-jonmo`, `kartiker-moyur-bahon`, `gonesh-kartik-bibad`

**Files moved (3):**
- `articles/durga-slays-mahishasura/` ‚Üí `stories/durga-slays-mahishasura/` (links updated)
- `articles/goddess-saraswati/` ‚Üí `stories/goddess-saraswati/` (links updated)
- `articles/kali-mata/` ‚Üí `stories/kali-mata/` (links updated)

**Files deleted:**
- `frontend/src/app/articles/` directory (entirely removed)

**Files modified (3):**
- `Header.tsx` ‚Äî Nav link changed from `/articles` "Articles" ‚Üí `/stories` "Stories" (desktop + mobile)
- `Footer.tsx` ‚Äî Community link changed from `/articles` "Articles" ‚Üí `/stories` "Stories"
- `sitemap.ts` ‚Äî Removed `/articles` URLs, added `/stories` + all 15 individual story/article URLs

**Build:** Passes cleanly with 34 static pages generated. The feature branch `feature/children-stories-section` is ready for review.
